::: left ::: fragment 1. Skips unchanged code/ steps ğŸƒ ::: ::: fragment 2. Evidence that `code = results` ğŸ”¬ ::: ::: fragment 3. Produces code dependency graphs ğŸ¦¾ ::: ::: fragment 4. Makes parallel computing easy ğŸ”€ ::: :::
::: notes - Watches the workflow and skips steps (targets) whose code, data & upstream dependencies have not changed. - When all targets are up to date, evidence that results match the code. - Trust results. - Confirm computation is reproducible ::: ------------------------------------------------------------------------
"{`targets`} implicitly nudges users toward a clean, function-oriented programming style that fits the intent of the R language"
------------------------------------------------------------------------ ## Setup

::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} install.packages("targets") ``` ::: ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ## Create an R project

::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} usethis::create_project(path = r"(C:\Users\jtufts\Documents\targets-demo)") ``` :::
::: callout-tip
Quick plug that you can use my package to create a pre-populated R project directory! ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} dauRtemplate::dau_proj_template(path = r"(C:\Users\jtufts\Documents\targets-demo)") ``` :::
More information here: [https://github.com/JT-39/dau-R-template-ext]({{< env url_dauR_template >}}){target="_blank"}
::: ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ## Develop your data pipeline

The project directory could look something like...
``` {.bash .code code-line-numbers="false"} â”œâ”€â”€ analysis.R â”œâ”€â”€ _data/ â”‚ â”œâ”€â”€ raw_data.csv â”œâ”€â”€ R/ â”‚ â”œâ”€â”€ functions.R ``` ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ## Absence data
![](_images/absence_data.png){style="border: 2px solid grey;"} ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ## analysis.R
::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} source(here::here("src/R/functions.R")) # Path to absence data absence_data_file_path <- here::here("_data/raw/1_absence_3term_nat_reg_la.csv") # Extract national absence and format date df_nat_absence <- get_nat_absence_data(absence_data_file_path) |> format_time_period() # Fit a linear model model <- fit_model(df_nat_absence) # Plot the data and model plot_model(model, df_nat_absence) ``` ::: ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ## functions.R
::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # Pull national absence from file get_nat_absence_data <- function(file_path) { read.csv(file = file_path) |> dplyr::filter(geographic_level == "National") } # Extract the start year from academic year extract_year <- function(date) { paste0(substr(date, 1, 4)) } # Format the year as a date format_time_period <- function(data) { data |> dplyr::mutate(Date = lubridate::year(as.Date(extract_year(time_period), format = "%Y")), .after=time_period) } # Fit the model and pull coefficients fit_model <- function(data) { lm(sess_overall_percent_pa_10_exact ~ Date, data) |> coefficients() } # Round to the nearets multiple of five round_to_multiple_five <- function(x) { ceiling((x + 1)/5)*5 } # Plot the data and model plot_model <- function(model, data) { ggplot2::ggplot(data) + ggplot2::geom_point(ggplot2::aes(x = Date, y = sess_overall_percent_pa_10_exact, colour = school_type)) + ggplot2::geom_line(ggplot2::aes(x = Date, y = sess_overall_percent_pa_10_exact, colour = school_type)) + ggplot2::scale_colour_manual(values = kasstylesr::color_picker(4), breaks = c("Total", "State-funded primary", "State-funded secondary", "Special")) + ggplot2::geom_abline(intercept = model[1], slope = model[2], show.legend = T, colour="red", linetype="dashed") + ggplot2::annotate("text", x = max(data$Date), y = lm(sess_overall_percent_pa_10_exact ~ Date, df_nat_absence) |> fitted.values() |> max(), hjust = -0.45, label = "Line of best fit", colour = "red") + ggplot2::scale_y_continuous(breaks = scales::pretty_breaks(), limits = function(x) { c(0, round_to_multiple_five(max(x))) }) + ggplot2::coord_cartesian(clip = 'off') + ggplot2::theme_minimal() + kasstylesr::kas_style() + ggplot2::labs( title = "Average persistent absence over time in England", subtitle = "Split by school type. Only includes persistent absentees.", x = "", y = "Overall absence rate (%)", colour = "School type:" ) } ``` ::: ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ## Now make a {targets} pipeline

``` {.bash .code code-line-numbers="false"} â”œâ”€â”€ _targets_analysis.R* â”œâ”€â”€ _data/ â”‚ â”œâ”€â”€ raw_data.csv â”œâ”€â”€ R/ â”‚ â”œâ”€â”€ functions.R ``` ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ## Create a {targets} template
::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} targets::tar_script() ``` :::
![](_images/tar_script.png){style="border: 2px solid grey;"} ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ## There are 3 parts to the pipeline
::: {.fragment .fade-in-then-semi-out} 1. Packages are loaded ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} library(targets) ``` ::: ::: ::: {.fragment .fade-in-then-semi-out} 2. Pipeline-specific options are set ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} tar_option_set(packages = "utils") tar_source(here::here("R/functions.R")) ``` ::: ::: ::: {.fragment .fade-in} 3. The pipeline itself, a series of *targets* ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} list( tar_target(name = data, command = data.frame(x = sample.int(100), y = sample.int(100))), tar_target(name = data_summary, command = summarize_data(data)) ) ``` ::: :::
::: notes - Due to the execution of the pipeline in parallel, load packages used in pipeline seperately. - So the pkgs are available to all workers. - At the top of the script, think â€œpipeline infrastructureâ€ packages ({targets} and some others). - Inside tar_option_set() think â€œfunctions that run inside the pipelineâ€ packages. ::: ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ## The {targets} pipeline

::: {.fragment .fade-in-then-semi-out} - It is simply a list of *targets* ğŸ¯ ::: ::: {.fragment .fade-in-then-semi-out} - A target is defined using `tar_target()` ::: ::: {.fragment .fade-in} - Each has 2 necessary inputs - `name` - `command` \~ the function that generates the target :::
------------------------------------------------------------------------ ## The {targets} pipeline
::: fragment So... a target defined as: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} tar_target(name = y, command = f(x)) ``` ::: :::
::: {.fragment .fade-in} Can be understood as: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} y <- f(x) ``` ::: :::
::: {.fragment .fade-in} - Targets after this can use the output of previous targets :::
::: notes - A target is really just a step in the analysis pipeline ::: ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ## The {targets} pipeline
![](./_images/targets_pipeline.png){style="border: 2px solid grey;"} ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ## Build the pipeline

::: {.cell} ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} tar_make(script = "src/_targets_analysis.R") ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` > dispatched target data_file o completed target data_file [3.21 seconds] > dispatched target nat_data o completed target nat_data [0.63 seconds] > dispatched target nat_data_clean o completed target nat_data_clean [0.01 seconds] > dispatched target model o completed target model [0.01 seconds] Saving 7 x 7 in image > dispatched target plot o completed target plot [7.87 seconds] > ended pipeline [12.12 seconds] ``` ::: ::: ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ## An empty global environment?
![](_images/empty_environment.png){style="border: 2px solid grey;"} ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ## What is going on?

::: {.fragment .fade-in-then-semi-out} - {`targets`} creates a pipeline of pure functions ::: ::: {.fragment .fade-in-then-semi-out} - Running the pipeline does not depend on the global environment ğŸŒ ::: ::: {.fragment .fade-in-then-semi-out} - It also does not change anything outside its scope ğŸ”­ ::: ::: {.fragment .fade-in-then-semi-out} - The pipeline is **PURE** :::
------------------------------------------------------------------------ ## _targets/

::: {.fragment .fade-in-then-semi-out} - The outputs are stored in `_targets/objects/` ::: ::: {.fragment .fade-in-then-semi-out} - Each target is saved as an object in the `.rds` format ::: ::: {.fragment .fade-in-then-semi-out} - So, you **MUST** add `_targets/` to `.gitignore` (for GitHub) â˜ï¸ :::
------------------------------------------------------------------------ ## _targets/
::: {.fragment .fade-in} ```{.bash .code code-line-numbers="false"} _targets/ â”œâ”€â”€ meta â”‚ â”œâ”€â”€ meta â”‚ â”œâ”€â”€ process â”‚ â””â”€â”€ progress â”œâ”€â”€ objects â”‚ â”œâ”€â”€ model â”‚ â”œâ”€â”€ nat_data â”‚ â””â”€â”€ nat_data_clean â””â”€â”€ user ``` :::
::: {.fragment .fade-in-then} ![](_images/_targets_objects.png){style="border: 2px solid grey;"} ::: ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ## _targets/
::: {.fragment .fade-in-then-out} To display targets: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} tar_read(model) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` (Intercept) Date 3153.093497 -1.549805 ``` ::: ::: :::
::: {.fragment .fade-in-then-out} To load targets into the global environment: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} tar_load(model) ``` ::: :::
::: notes - Well not strictly pure... - `.rds` is a R-specific format to save *any* type of object - Can be save and read with `saveRDS()` and `readRDS()` - Also should note that the pipeline is composition of pure functions. - Pure functions: - Referentially transparent function is a function that does not use any variable that is not also one of its inputs. - A function that does not interact in any way with the global environment. - Functions with only side-effects will be difficult to handle. For example, `base::plot()` ::: ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ## Handling files
::: {.callout-warning title="Advanced"}
::: {.fragment .fade-in} - **MUST** use the data's file path initially (and `format = "file"`) ::: ::: {.fragment .fade-in} ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} targets::tar_target( name = data, command = here::here("_data/raw/1_absence_3term_nat_reg_la.csv"), format = "file" ) ``` ::: ::: ::: {.fragment .fade-in} - Then use the file path target to read in the data ::: ::: {.fragment .fade-in} ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} targets::tar_target( name = nat_data, command = read.csv(data) ) ``` ::: ::: ::: {.fragment .fade-in} - Otherwise, {`targets`} will not track the data (any changes to it) :::
::: ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ## File Big Brother

::: {.fragment .fade-in-then-semi-out} - {`targets`} keeps track of changes in files and functions ğŸ•µï¸ ::: ::: {.fragment .fade-in-then-semi-out} - Any changes will result in the targets being identified as out-of-date ::: ::: {.fragment .fade-in-then-semi-out} - So, are re-computed (and their dependencies) ::: ::: {.fragment .fade-in-then-semi-out} - We can visualise this... :::
------------------------------------------------------------------------ ## Code dependency graph
![](./_images/complete_code_dependency_graph.png){style="border: 2px solid grey;"} ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ## Let's change something

::: {.fragment .fade-in} - We now filter out the years 2020 & 2021 ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} format_time_period <- function(data) { data |> ... |> dplyr::filter(Date %in% c(2020, 2021)) } ``` ::: :::
------------------------------------------------------------------------ ## Let's change something
::: {.fragment .fade-in width="450" height="300"} ![](./_images/incomplete_code_dependency_graph.png){style="border: 2px solid grey;"} ::: ::: notes - The graph will also highlight in red if there is an error in the pipeline. ::: ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ## Parallel computation
::: {.fragment .fade-in-then-semi-out} - Can run any independent steps (*targets*) in parallel ğŸ”€ ::: ::: {.fragment .fade-in-then-semi-out} - We are able to harness any GPU cores available, cutting computation time âœ‚ï¸ ::: ::: {.fragment .fade-in-then-semi-out} - {`targets`} knows which parts of the pipeline can be ran in parallel ::: ::: {.fragment .fade-in-then-semi-out} - To set this up... :::
::: notes - Also could be useful on DataBricks where more cores and nodes may be available. ::: ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ## Parallel computation
::: {.fragment .fade-in-then-out} Need to load a few more packages: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} library(targets) library(future) library(future.callr) plan(callr) ``` ::: ::: ::: {.fragment .fade-in-then-out} Utilise the {`targets`} function to run in parallel: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # Set workers = 2 to use 2 cpu cores targets::tar_make_future(workers = 2) ``` ::: ::: ::: {.fragment .fade-in} Simple as that! ğŸ’¥ :::
::: notes - Most of our laptops have around 7 cores. - Don't use all the cores though as some are needed for background computer stuff! ::: ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ::: center ## Other features ğŸ”® ::: ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ## RMarkdown & Quarto
::: {.fragment .fade-in-then-semi-out} - Can include the rendering of a `.Rmd` or `.qmd` to the pipeline ::: ::: {.fragment .fade-in-then-semi-out} - Utilises the power of the {`targets`} computation ğŸ”‹ :::
::: r-stack ::: {.fragment .fade-in-then-out} Load package needed ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} libray(tarchetypes) ``` ::: ::: ::: {.fragment .fade-in-then-out} Function to render Quarto file in the pipeline ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} tar_render( my_doc, "my_document.qmd" ) ``` ::: ::: ::: {.fragment .fade-in-then-out} How to load targets in the Quarto file ```{{r}} tar_read(plot) ``` ::: :::
------------------------------------------------------------------------ ## SQL
::: {.fragment .fade-in-then-out} - When executing code to SQL you will need to create connect and disconnect each time ğŸ”Œ ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} function(yml_key) { conn <- connect_sql_db(yml_key) on.exit(DBI::dbDisconnect(conn, shutdown = TRUE)) DBI::dbGetQuery(...)} ``` ::: ::: ::: {.fragment .fade-in} - Also the package {`sqltargets`} which applies {`targets`} principles to .sql files ğŸ“¦ ::: ::: r-stack ::: {.fragment .fade-in-then-out} ::: {.cell} ```{.sql .cell-code} -- !preview conn=DBI::dbConnect(RSQLite::SQLite()) -- tar_load(query_params) select id from table where age > {age_threshold} ``` ::: ::: ::: {.fragment .fade-in} ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} tar_sql(query, path = "query.sql", query_params = query_params) ``` ::: ::: :::
::: notes - SQL connection repetitio is to ensure the connection is closed and is reusable ::: ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ## Key takeaways

::: {.fragment .fade-in-then-semi-out} - Enforces a modular, function based pipelines âœ…
(R best practice!) ::: ::: {.fragment .fade-in-then-semi-out} - Tracks changes to datasets and functions ğŸ” ::: ::: {.fragment .fade-in-then-semi-out} - Provides efficient computation of pipelines â™»ï¸ :::
------------------------------------------------------------------------ ::: center ## We've hit the target! ğŸ¯ ::: ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ## Resources, links and email
- {targets} manual: [Link]({{< env targets_pkg_manual >}}){target="_blank"} - YouTube {targets} walkthrough: [Link]({{< env youtube_targets >}}){target="_blank"} - Ofsted MI {targets} example pipeline GitHub: [Link]({{< env ofsted_mi_github >}}){target="_blank"} - These slides and mini {targets} example GitHub: [Link]({{< env slides_github >}}){target="_blank"} - {sqltargets} GitHub: [Link]({{< env sql_targets_git >}}){target="_blank"} Email me at: jake.tufts@education.gov.uk

<script>
  // htmlwidgets need to know to resize themselves when slides are shown/hidden.
  // Fire the "slideenter" event (handled by htmlwidgets.js) when the current
  // slide changes (different for each slide format).
  (function () {
    // dispatch for htmlwidgets
    function fireSlideEnter() {
      const event = window.document.createEvent("Event");
      event.initEvent("slideenter", true, true);
      window.document.dispatchEvent(event);
    }

    function fireSlideChanged(previousSlide, currentSlide) {
      fireSlideEnter();

      // dispatch for shiny
      if (window.jQuery) {
        if (previousSlide) {
          window.jQuery(previousSlide).trigger("hidden");
        }
        if (currentSlide) {
          window.jQuery(currentSlide).trigger("shown");
        }
      }
    }

    // hookup for slidy
    if (window.w3c_slidy) {
      window.w3c_slidy.add_observer(function (slide_num) {
        // slide_num starts at position 1
        fireSlideChanged(null, w3c_slidy.slides[slide_num - 1]);
      });
    }

  })();
</script>
